contentrichtext.text: {{EngvarB|date=June 2013}} [[File:Linguicabrazil.jpg|thumb|right|190px|''Linguiça'' for sale in [[Espirito Santo]], Brazil]] '''''Linguiça''''' ({{IPA-pt|lĩˈɡwisɐ}}) is a form of smoke cured [[pork]] [[sausage]] seasoned with [[garlic]] and [[paprika]] in Portuguese-speaking countries. ''Linguiça'', like many other sausages, is generally served as part of a heavy meal, typically accompanied by rice, beans, and other pork products. ''[[Feijoada]]'', for example, is a traditional [[Brazil|Brazilian]] dish, also common in [[Angola]], that incorporates ''linguiça'' with [[bean]]s, [[ham hock]]s, and other foods.<ref name="copacabana-feijoada">{{cite web | publisher = Copacabana.info | date = 2008 | url = http://www.copacabana.info/feijoada.html | title = Brazilian Feijoada Recipe and History | accessdate = 2008-04-22}}</ref> In Brazil, one variant is specially popular, the ''linguiça calabresa'' or simply ''calabresa'', prepared originally with Calabrese pepper (nowadays with South American pepper) by Italian immigrants and particularly used in pizzas as a spicy sausage. Its popularity compares with [[pepperoni]] in the United States. Thus its common to differentiate the ''linguiça calabresa'' from its counterpart ''linguiça portuguesa'', prepared from the original Portuguese recipe and also served in pizzas as mild sausage, generally with egg slices. Outside of continental [[Portugal]], [[Azores Islands]], Madeira Islands and [[Brazil]], ''linguiça'' is also popular in [[Goa]], [[Southeastern Massachusetts]], [[North Shore (Massachusetts)|Massachusetts' North Shore]], [[California]], [[Oregon]], [[Seattle]], [[New Jersey]], [[Hawaii]], and [[Okinawa]]. It is also available in many grocery stores in southern [[New Hampshire]], and southern [[Maine]]. In these regions it is typically sliced before being braised or grilled. ''Linguiça'' is also used in ''[[Francesinha]]'', a traditional Portuguese dish, from [[Porto]]. The ''linguiça'' is incorporated in its sauce, giving it a distinct flavor.<ref name = "linguica-molho-francesinha">{{cite web | publisher = Petitchef | date = 2008 | url = http://pt.petitchef.com/receitas/molho-francesinha-mais-simples-fid-115153 | title = Lingüiça in Francesinha Dish | accessdate = 2009-01-01]}}</ref> In Hawaii, [[McDonald's]] restaurants serve breakfasts featuring ''linguiça''. Hawaiian ''linguiça'', also known as Portuguese sausage, is usually smoked using banana leaves.<ref name="bizjournals-mcdonalds-spam">{{cite web | publisher = Pacific Business News | date = 2002-06-11 | url = http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/stories/2002/06/10/daily22.html | title = McDonald's test-markets Spam | accessdate = 2008-04-22}}</ref> ''Linguiça'' is a popular dish in [[Mangalore]] among the Catholic community. Mangalorean ''linguiça'' is spicier than Portuguese ''linguiça'', and is more closely related to [[Goan chouriço]]. It is strongly flavored with red chillies, peppercorns, turmeric, and salt. It is typically prepared by half frying onions, adding sugar and vinegar to the meat, and cooking over a low flame, preferably wood fire. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{dmoz|/Home/Cooking/World_Cuisines/European/Portuguese/|Portuguese cooking}} <!--==========================({{NoMoreLinks}})============================ | PLEASE BE CAUTIOUS IN ADDING MORE LINKS TO THIS ARTICLE.
